CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-1;Just satisfaction dismissed (out of time)
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG expropriated a plot of land belonging to the applicant . A committee of experts assessed the value of the plot and the relevant amount was paid to him when the expropriation took place .
CARDINAL . Following the applicant ’s request for increased compensation , on DATE ORG of First - instance awarded him additional compensation plus interest at the statutory rate .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of First - instance awarded the applicant an additional compensation of GPE NORP liras ( GPE ) plus interest at the statutory rate applicable at the date of the court ’s decision running from DATE , the date on which the title deed to the land had been transferred to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of the Firstinstance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the parties’ request for rectification .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG paid the amount of ORG to the applicant .

CARDINAL . After the application was communicated to the Government , the applicant was requested to submit his observations on the merits of the case and also her just satisfaction claims until DATE . However , he failed to submit them within the required time - limit . He did not request any extension of time , either .

CARDINAL . By registered letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant was informed that ORG had not received his observations and just satisfaction claims and that the ORG might strike a case out of its list of cases where the circumstances lead to the conclusion that the applicant did not intend to pursue the application .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted his observations containing his just satisfaction claims .
CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice are set out in the Aka v. GPE judgment of DATE ( Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-VI , pp . DATE , § § DATE ) .
